name: Rio de Janeiro
fun_fact: Fun fact: Rio's botequim (traditional bar) culture is so integral to Carioca life that there's a national gastronomy contest called 'Comida di Buteco' where botecos from 25 Brazilian cities compete for best bar food. The word 'boteco' comes from Greek 'apoth√©ke' meaning small grocery store - these spots became meeting points that evolved into Brazil's icons of sociability and culture.

hero_dishes.description: Teardrop-shaped croquette stuffed with seasoned shredded chicken and catupiry cheese, deep-fried until golden and crispy
hero_dishes.origin_story: Name means 'little thigh' in Portuguese, inspired by chicken drumstick shape. Originated in S√£o Paulo in 19th century as a Brazilian adaptation of French 'croquette de poulet.' Cariocas love it so much there's a National Coxinha Day. It's the quintessential Brazilian street food.

hero_dishes.name: Pastel
hero_dishes.description: Rectangular fried pastry with high-fat dough, filled with dried meat, shredded chicken, shrimp, or cheese - often served with fresh sugarcane juice
hero_dishes.origin_story: The legendary motivator that drags Rio locals out of bed for Sunday markets. Differentiates itself with airy, high-fat dough. The pastel-and-sugarcane-juice combo is a sacred Sunday ritual at feiras (markets).
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Feira da Gl√≥ria (Sunday mornings, local favorite); S√£o Crist√≥v√£o Feira Nordestina (massive indoor market); neighborhood Sunday markets citywide

hero_dishes.name: Botequim Petiscos
hero_dishes.description: Traditional bar appetizers: bolinhos de bacalhau (codfish fritters), kibe, esfiha, churrasquinho skewers, queijo coalho (grilled cheese)
hero_dishes.origin_story: The soul of Rio's food scene lives in botequims - family-run bars where Cariocas gather for ice-cold chopp (draft beer) and petiscos with friends. These aren't restaurants; they're confraternization places with laid-back informality.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Bar Luiz (since 1887, Rua da Carioca 39, German-Brazilian, bolinho de bacalhau); Cosmopolita (since 1950, Travessa do Mosqueira 4, honest Portuguese-Brazilian food under R$30); Garota da Urca (grab petiscos, sit on seawall, peak Rio)

hero_dishes.origin_story: Where post-night-out Cariocas refuel. Open until dawn, this sandwich shop represents Rio's late-night food culture - the sweet-savory combo is pure Rio creativity.

signature_drinks.name: Caipirinha
signature_drinks.description: Brazil's national cocktail - cacha√ßa (sugarcane hard liquor), sugar, and lime
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Icy cold at botequims, often customized with different fruits (passion fruit, strawberry). Standard accompaniment to Saturday afternoon feijoada or beach hangs. Beach vendors shout 'Caipirinha!' along the sand.

signature_drinks.name: Mate Gelado
signature_drinks.description: Cold, sweetened tea made from yerba mate leaves
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Beach vendors walk the sand shouting 'Mate gelado!' - it's THE authentic beach drink. Part of Rio's beach culture ritual alongside caipirinhas and coconut water.

signature_drinks.name: Chopp (Draft Beer)
signature_drinks.description: Ice-cold draft beer, the botequim staple
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served in small glasses to stay cold. Locals order round after round while eating petiscos and socializing for hours. Temperature is crucial - must be 'stupidamente gelada' (stupidly cold).
